--- Comment #8 from Dirk Eddelbuettel (<mailto:edd@debian.org|edd@debian.org>) ---
Like me, some of you following this issue may have missed that Martin reverted
these commits on Dec 23 as they were seen to have fairly widespread negative
side effects across a number of packages.  So using the preprocessor may be too
blunt a tool.  

An alternative may be using function declarations instead.  One can use
`inline` in C along with an appropriate attribute with at least some compilers.
 Would this be viable across all the compilers R uses?

--- Comment #9 from Mikael Jagan (<mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>) ---
Created attachment 3436
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3436&action=edit>
amend attachment 3430 to remap also if compiling/linking standalone Mathlib

(In reply to Suharto Anggono from comment #7)
Indeed, attachment 3430 should have included

```
@@ -200,7 +200,7 @@
 #endif


-#if !defined(MATHLIB_STANDALONE) && !defined(R_NO_REMAP_RMATH)
+#if !defined(R_NO_REMAP_RMATH)
 #define bessel_i       Rf_bessel_i
 #define bessel_j       Rf_bessel_j
 #define bessel_k       Rf_bessel_k
```

so that compiling/linking standalone Mathlib would continue to work.  As
mentioned by Suharto (and not noticed by me in comment 2; sorry ...), a change
implied by this patch is that the names of entry points in standalone Mathlib
are _newly_ prefixed with `Rf_`.  If that is not desirable, then, yes, a patch
along the lines of attachment 3432 would make sense ...

(To say nothing about the breakage seen on CRAN (all?/partly?) downstream of
`Rcpp/.../undoRmath.h`, which I've not had time to investigate/understand over
the holiday ...)

--- Comment #10 from Dirk Eddelbuettel (<mailto:edd@debian.org|edd@debian.org>) ---
Ahem, that most recent breakage was *not* due to Rcpp; what we do there is in a
namespace and worked for 10+ years.

Recent breakage from this issue here included eg package like `terra` which
happens to have an internal object with a member dataframe object named `df`. 
Which the `#define` on `df` -> `Rf_df` prevents from compiling as the
preprocessor is such a blunt tool that one can no longer have a member variable
named `df`.
